mods.abstract: Black students leave the campus after vacating the Allen Administration Building in the wake of its takeover to protest the campus racial climate.

titleInfo.title: Policeman in Tear Gas at Allen Building Takeover

mods.abstract: Duke students take over the Allen Building on west campus. A member of the N.C. Highway Patrol, with riot stick in hand, walks alongside a Durham police officer as he dispenses tear gas on campus to disperse the mob.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Policemen at Allen Building Takeover

mods.abstract: Duke students take over the Allen Building on west campus. Members of the N.C. Highway Patrol and the Durham Police with riot sticks and tear gas gun in hand, stand in front of side entrance to the Allen Building on Duke's west campus.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: William McBroom as \"Black Santa\" for \"Black Christmas\" Parade

mods.abstract: Durham's first recorded Black Christmas Parade with its own Black Santa. The parade route was along Fayetteville St. in the Hayti community. William McBroom plays \"Black Santa\" for the Selective Buying Campaign's alternative Christmas parade.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: R. Kelly Bryant and Santa Claus (William McBroom) at \"Black Christmas\" Parade

mods.abstract: N.C. Mutual executive R. Kelly Bryant, Jr., tosses lollipops, and Santa Claus (William McBroom) receives onlookers' cheers during a \"Black Christmas\" parade. Sponsored by the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement as part of its boycott of certain white-owned businesses, the parade was held on Fayetteville Street at the same time as the Durham Merchants Association's traditional parade downtown.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Lloyd Jacobs, KKK \"King Kleagle\", Next to James Young Outside City Hall

mods.abstract: Lloyd Jacobs, a Durham house painter and \"king kleagle\" of the Ku Klux Klan, displays his displeasure at what James W. Young, a North Carolina Central University professor, has to say outside Durham City Hall.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Police Vigil Over Main Street During Curfew After Firebombings Following Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.

mods.abstract: Moore photographed this police officer standing vigil over a deserted Main Street during the curfew following the assassination of Martin Luther King in Memphis. He also photographed firebombings of several Durham businesses that led to the curfew. \"The '60s were probably the best time for photojournalism,\" Moore said. \"You didn't feel safe at times, but you knew you needed to be there.\"

subject.topic: Civil rights demonstrations--North Carolina--Durham; King, Martin Luther, Jr., 1929-1968--Assassination

mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Firefighters Battling Fire Set in Protest of Death of Martin Luther King, Jr.

mods.abstract: Durham firemen battling fire at Couch's Furniture Store on Ninth Street, which was one of several buildings set on fire to protest the death of Martin Luther King, Jr.

titleInfo.title: Martin Luther King, Jr. at White Rock Baptist Church

mods.abstract: After Martin Luther King visited the segregated lunch counter at Woolworth's department store in downtown Durham. Moore covered the civil right's leader's speech that night at the old White Rock Baptist Church on Fayetteville Street. \"He wasn't drawing media attention that much then,\" Moore said. \"As far as I recall I was the only photographer there.\"
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Malcolm X at Page Auditorium

mods.abstract: Malcolm X (born Malcolm Little), a gifted orator and advocate for radical political action to advance black interests, appeared in Page’s Auditorium on Roxboro Street. He debated Durham resident Floyd McKissick, an NAACP lawyer and civil rights activist, before a standing-room-only crowd, roughly 75 percent black and many of whom were students. Originally scheduled at W. D. Hill Recreation Center, the program was moved after city officials canceled the reservation on the grounds that the Black Muslims were not a religious group, as they had stated. McKissick declared that the city “stomped on the first amendment” to the Constitution when it denied the use of the hall for the debate.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Malcolm X at Page Auditorium

mods.abstract: Malcolm X speaking to a crowd at rally in Durham. The rally had been scheduled for the NCCU campus, but was banned, and moved to a lodge on North Roxboro St.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Martin Luther King, Jr., Ralph Abernathy and Douglas Moore at Woolworth

mods.abstract: Martin Luther King, Jr. visits Woolworth in downtown Durham with Robert Abernathy and Douglas Moore, pastor of Asbury Temple Methodist Church in Durham. The identity of the man on the far right is unknown.

titleInfo.title: Roy Wilkins, Floyd McKissick and James Farmer at Howard Johnson's

mods.abstract: Civil rights demonstrators in front of Howard Johnson's on Chapel Hill Boulevard in Durham. They are (left to right) Roy Wilkins, executive director of the NAACP; Floyd McKissick, civil rights attorney; and James Farmer, executive with CORE.

titleInfo.title: NC Central and Hillside High Students Demonstrate at City Hall

mods.abstract: Demonstrators from NC College (now N.C. Central University) and Hillside High School gather on the Durham County Courthouse steps to show support for 130 demonstrators arrested while trying to integrate eating establishments.

titleInfo.title: Crowd at Howard Johnson's

mods.abstract: A crowd estimated at 500 people demonstrates against segregation at Howard Johnson's Restaurant on the Durham-Chapel Hill Boulevard. Sunday afternoon protests at the restaurant went on for almost a year, until mass demonstrations in May 1963 led to integration of most eating establishments in Durham.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.

mods.abstract: A Carolina Theatre manager confronts prospective black patrons in the lobby.

mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Round-Robin Protest at Carolina Theatre

mods.abstract: A \"round-robin\" demonstrator asks to buy a ticket to the Carolina Theatre and gets a refusal at the box office. Once turned away, protestors went to the end of the line and waited their turns to try again.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Protestors Confronted by Police at Carolina Theatre

mods.abstract: An unidentified protestor is confronted by a Durham police officer and Carolina Theatre assistant manager Milo Crawford. Demonstrators were advised not to give their names to police for fear of white reprisals.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Round-Robin Protest at Carolina Theatre

mods.abstract: A line of \"round-robin\" protesters extends along Manning Place from the Carolina Theatre box office past city hall (now Durham Arts Council Building).
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Round-Robin Protest at Carolina Theatre

mods.abstract: The line of \"round-robin\" demonstrators stretches from the Carolina Theatre box office west along Manning Place. Denied tickets, marchers would return to the end of the line and wait for another turn.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Demonstrators Passing by National Guardsmen

mods.abstract: Demonstrators pass National Guardsmen, stationed in the Sears Roebuck parking lot along Peabody Street, on their way to a civil rights rally in front of City Hall.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: North Carolina Central and Hillside High Students Demonstrate at City Hall

mods.abstract: Students from North Carolina College (now North Carolina Central University) and Hillside High School demonstrate at city hall. Theirs was one of several simultaneous protests in Durham, which continued for four days and led to 850 arrests.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Martin Luther King, Jr. at Hillside High School

mods.abstract: In one of his earlier visits to Durham, Martin Luther King, Jr., addresses the student body of Hillside High School.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Martin Luther King, Jr. and others walking on Main Street

mods.abstract: Martin Luther King, Jr. walks along West Main Street toward Woolworth. From left to right: Douglas Moore, pastor of the Asbury Temple Methodist Church in Durham; King; and Ralph Abernathy. The identity of person on the far right is unknown.
mods.accessCondition: This image is part of the Durham Herald Co. Newspaper Photograph Collection at Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Martin Luther King, Jr. and others walking on Main Street

mods.abstract: Martin Luther King, Jr. walks along West Main Street toward Woolworth. From left to right: Douglas Moore, pastor of the Asbury Temple Methodist Church in Durham; King; and Ralph Abernathy. The person on the far right may be Lacy Streeter, student at North Carolina Central University.

titleInfo.title: Selective Buying Campaign Flyer

name.namePart: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement

mods.abstract: The Selective Buying Campaign began in July 1968, when an organization called the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement issued a 15-page memorandum to the Durham Chamber of Commerce and Merchants Association, demanding changes in welfare, housing, and employment policies in the city. The boycott lasted until February 16, 1969.
mods.accessCondition: From the R. Kelly Bryant Papers, North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Selective Buying Campaign Boycott Flyer

name.namePart: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement

mods.abstract: Northgate Shopping Center, and downtown branches of businesses located there, were the first target of the Black Solidarity Committee's boycott in July 1968. By the middle of August, 14 other firms had been added to its do-not-patronize list as the committee sought to pressure the chamber of commerce and Durham Merchants Association to use their influence on behalf of its demands.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Nathan Thomas and Eugene Hampton next to Hampton's City Council campaign sign

mods.abstract: Campaign manager Nathan Thomas (left) stands with Durham City Council candidate Eugene Hampton. Hampton was one of three black candidates for council seats. He lost a runoff to a white incumbent.

titleInfo.title: Durham Sun Article in Advance of Royal Ice Cream Sit-in

mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Photograph of Royal Ice Cream Sit-in Participants

mods.abstract: Pictured here is the group which was arrested and convicted of trespassing in Durham last Saturday when they entered the Royal Ice Cream Company from the side used by whites only. Left to right, front row, are Mary Clyburn, Virginia Williams, Rev. Douglas E. Moore, Vivian Jones. Back row, same order, are Jesse Gray, Claude Glenn, and Melvin H. Willis. Nation's first sit-in case.
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Royal Ice Cream Strikers Praying

mods.abstract: The Royal Ice Cream strikers pray before going to court. \"It was exciting, because we went where we dared not to go. I wasn't frightened or anything of that sort because either way, we could have made history. If he had served us ice cream, he would have made history. But, by refusing to, I guess we made history!\" -Virginia Williams, Royal Ice Cream Protester, 2003 Interview
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.

titleInfo.title: Virginia Williams on Her Way to a Student Organizing Conference in Mississippi - MISSING SCAN

mods.abstract: A budding civil-rights crusader, Virginia Williams travels from Durham to a student organizing conference in Mississippi
mods.note: Item description, identifier (if applicable), Box and Folder information. Durham Civil Rights Heritage Project (NCC.0040). North Carolina Collection, Durham County Library, NC.
